quoteFirst: Of the best wheat, one hundred pounds contain about eighty-five pounds of nutritious matter; of rice, ninety pounds; of rye, eighty; of barley, eighty-three; of beans, eighty-
quoteLast: ty-two; peas, ninety-three; lentils, ninety-four; meat (average), thirty-five; potatoes, twenty-five; beets, fourteen; carrots, ten; cabbage, seven; greens, six; and turnips, four.
title:
Vegetable Diet: As Sanctioned by Medical Men, and by Experience in All Ages
Including a System of Vegetable Cookery
author: Alcott, William A. (William Andrus), 1798-1859

quoteFirst: The black or yellow locust is a beautiful tree in its youth, with smooth dark rind and slender trunk, holding up a loose roundish head of dark green foliage. Each leaf is eight to fourteen inches long, of
quoteLast: teen leaflets, silvery when they unfold, and always paler beneath. In late May, the tree-top bursts into bloom that is often so profuse as to whiten the whole mass of the dainty foliage.
title: Trees Worth Knowing
author: Rogers, Julia Ellen, 1866-

quoteFirst: The faces of old men brightened when they saw her, and one or two ancient figures who, for years, had been seldom seen at social functions now came when they knew she was to be present.  There were, of course, a few women who said she would coquette with any male from
quoteLast: ty; but no man ever said so; and there was none, from first to last, but smiled with pleasure at even the mention of her name, so had her vivacity, intelligence, and fine sympathy conquered them.  She was a social artist by instinct.  In their hearts they all recognised how fair and impartial she was; and she drew out of every man the best that was in him.
title: Northern Lights, Volume 2.
author: Parker, Gilbert, 1862-1932

quoteFirst: In January that body resolved that it was incumbent upon the judges to determine at once whether they would receive their salaries direct from the crown, or depend therefor upon the votes of the Assembly. Chief-justice Oliver was questioned upon this point, and replied that he should hereafter look to the crown for the emoluments of office. The Assembly then resolved, by a majority of sixty-
quoteLast: , "That Peter Oliver hath, by his conduct, proved himself an enemy to the Constitution of the province, and is become greatly obnoxious to the good people of it; that he ought to be removed from the office of chief justice; and that a remonstrance and petition to the governor and Council, for his immediate removal, be prepared.
title:
The Pictorial Field-Book of the Revolution, Vol. 1 (of 2)
or, Illustrations, by Pen And Pencil, of the History, Biography, Scenery, Relics, and Traditions of the War for Independence
author: Lossing, Benson John, 1813-1891

quoteFirst: Bryant replied, and the result was that two members of the majority of the committee voted to sustain their nullification report, four, including the one who reported the bill to the house, voted against their own report, and the bill was defeated by a vote of two hundred and seventy-
quoteLast: teen. He had a natural gift for the position, and left the speaker's chair with the respect of all for his ability, his fairness, and his unvarying courtesy as a presiding officer.
title: Sketches of Successful New Hampshire Men
author: Various; Clarke, John B. (John Badger), 1820-1891 [Publisher]

quoteFirst: The faces of old men brightened when they saw her, and one or two ancient figures who, for years, had been seldom seen at social functions now came when they knew she was to be present.  There were, of course, a few women who said she would coquette with any male from

She was a social artist by instinct.  In their hearts they all recognised how fair and impartial she was; and she drew out of every man the best that was in him.

quoteFirst: Now and then I would raise my head above the grass to get a look at the elephants. The bull was a huge creature and seemed to be over ten feet in height,—the cows from
quoteLast: feet and a half. Finally I hid behind a tree, for I wanted to watch the noble animals at my ease. I noticed the big tusks of the bull and thought of his charging a man and impaling him upon them.
title: King Mombo
author: Du Chaillu, Paul B. (Paul Belloni), 1835-1903; Pérard, Victor Semon, 1870-1957 [Illustrator]
